result.markdown:
--- author: Thadryan title: "Stats Python in a Hurry Part 1: Data Wrangling" date: 2022-12-11 description: Transferring my R data-munging knowledge back to my first language. bibliography: Part1.bib toc: true --- > update: 12-17-22 - added sorting and table. # Data Manipulation ::: {.cell execution_count=1} ``` {.python .cell-code} import pandas as pd import numpy as np import statsmodels.api as sm ``` ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=2} ``` {.python .cell-code} # get a practice dataset df = sm.datasets.get_rdataset("mtcars", "datasets", cache = True).data df.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=2} ```{=html}
mpg cyl disp hp drat wt qsec vs am gear carb
Mazda RX4 21.0 6 160.0 110 3.90 2.620 16.46 0 1 4 4
Mazda RX4 Wag 21.0 6 160.0 110 3.90 2.875 17.02 0 1 4 4
Datsun 710 22.8 4 108.0 93 3.85 2.320 18.61 1 1 4 1
Hornet 4 Drive 21.4 6 258.0 110 3.08 3.215 19.44 1 0 3 1
Hornet Sportabout 18.7 8 360.0 175 3.15 3.440 17.02 0 0 3 2
``` ::: ::: ## Basics How to get basic information about the df. ### Dimensions of a df This is like `dim` in R. ::: {.cell execution_count=3} ``` {.python .cell-code} # rows by columns df.shape ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=3} ``` (32, 11) ``` ::: ::: ### Number of rows This is like `nrow` in R. ::: {.cell execution_count=4} ``` {.python .cell-code} # just the rows len(df) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=4} ``` 32 ``` ::: ::: ### Number of columns This is like `ncol` in R. ::: {.cell execution_count=5} ``` {.python .cell-code} # just the columns len(df.columns) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=5} ``` 11 ``` ::: ::: You could also just index the results of `df.shape`. ### Data types ::: {.cell execution_count=6} ``` {.python .cell-code} # a summary of types by column df.info() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Index: 32 entries, Mazda RX4 to Volvo 142E Data columns (total 11 columns): # Column Non-Null Count Dtype --- ------ -------------- ----- 0 mpg 32 non-null float64 1 cyl 32 non-null int64 2 disp 32 non-null float64 3 hp 32 non-null int64 4 drat 32 non-null float64 5 wt 32 non-null float64 6 qsec 32 non-null float64 7 vs 32 non-null int64 8 am 32 non-null int64 9 gear 32 non-null int64 10 carb 32 non-null int64 dtypes: float64(5), int64(6) memory usage: 3.0+ KB ``` ::: ::: ### Summary ::: {.cell execution_count=7} ``` {.python .cell-code} # summary of distributional information df.describe() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=7} ```{=html}
mpg cyl disp hp drat wt qsec vs am gear carb
count 32.000000 32.000000 32.000000 32.000000 32.000000 32.000000 32.000000 32.000000 32.000000 32.000000 32.0000
mean 20.090625 6.187500 230.721875 146.687500 3.596563 3.217250 17.848750 0.437500 0.406250 3.687500 2.8125
std 6.026948 1.785922 123.938694 68.562868 0.534679 0.978457 1.786943 0.504016 0.498991 0.737804 1.6152
min 10.400000 4.000000 71.100000 52.000000 2.760000 1.513000 14.500000 0.000000 0.000000 3.000000 1.0000
25% 15.425000 4.000000 120.825000 96.500000 3.080000 2.581250 16.892500 0.000000 0.000000 3.000000 2.0000
50% 19.200000 6.000000 196.300000 123.000000 3.695000 3.325000 17.710000 0.000000 0.000000 4.000000 2.0000
75% 22.800000 8.000000 326.000000 180.000000 3.920000 3.610000 18.900000 1.000000 1.000000 4.000000 4.0000
max 33.900000 8.000000 472.000000 335.000000 4.930000 5.424000 22.900000 1.000000 1.000000 5.000000 8.0000
``` ::: ::: ## Selections How to specify which column you want. ### Select a column Note that I'm using `head()` to get the first few rows to keep the output small. It's not part of the selection of columns. ::: {.cell execution_count=8} ``` {.python .cell-code} # access a single column like an object property df.mpg.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=8} ``` Mazda RX4 21.0 Mazda RX4 Wag 21.0 Datsun 710 22.8 Hornet 4 Drive 21.4 Hornet Sportabout 18.7 Name: mpg, dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: Or... ::: {.cell execution_count=9} ``` {.python .cell-code} # select a column (as a series) df["mpg"].head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=9} ``` Mazda RX4 21.0 Mazda RX4 Wag 21.0 Datsun 710 22.8 Hornet 4 Drive 21.4 Hornet Sportabout 18.7 Name: mpg, dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=10} ``` {.python .cell-code} # select column (as a dataframe) df[["mpg"]].head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=10} ```{=html}
mpg
Mazda RX4 21.0
Mazda RX4 Wag 21.0
Datsun 710 22.8
Hornet 4 Drive 21.4
Hornet Sportabout 18.7
``` ::: ::: ### Select several columns by string name ::: {.cell execution_count=11} ``` {.python .cell-code} # select a column by several names df[["mpg", "wt"]].head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=11} ```{=html}
mpg wt
Mazda RX4 21.0 2.620
Mazda RX4 Wag 21.0 2.875
Datsun 710 22.8 2.320
Hornet 4 Drive 21.4 3.215
Hornet Sportabout 18.7 3.440
``` ::: ::: ### Select from one column through another with names ::: {.cell execution_count=12} ``` {.python .cell-code} # select a range by name of start and end "mph through hp" df.loc[:, "mpg":"hp"].head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=12} ```{=html}
mpg cyl disp hp
Mazda RX4 21.0 6 160.0 110
Mazda RX4 Wag 21.0 6 160.0 110
Datsun 710 22.8 4 108.0 93
Hornet 4 Drive 21.4 6 258.0 110
Hornet Sportabout 18.7 8 360.0 175
``` ::: ::: ### Select arbitrarily How to get based on a condition of your choosing. We might want to get only columns that start with "d", for example. ::: {.cell execution_count=13} ``` {.python .cell-code} # get a list starts_with_d = [i for i in list(df.columns) if i.startswith("d")] # pass the list to pandas df[starts_with_d].head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=13} ```{=html}
disp drat
Mazda RX4 160.0 3.90
Mazda RX4 Wag 160.0 3.90
Datsun 710 108.0 3.85
Hornet 4 Drive 258.0 3.08
Hornet Sportabout 360.0 3.15
``` ::: ::: ## Filtering Operations where we'd used `dplyr` in R. In Pandas, filtering refers to operations by index, so what I'm thinking of is more like "querying" in Pandas terms. ### Single condition Pass logic in strings to the `query` method. ::: {.cell execution_count=14} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.query("cyl == 6") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=14} ```{=html}
mpg cyl disp hp drat wt qsec vs am gear carb
Mazda RX4 21.0 6 160.0 110 3.90 2.620 16.46 0 1 4 4
Mazda RX4 Wag 21.0 6 160.0 110 3.90 2.875 17.02 0 1 4 4
Hornet 4 Drive 21.4 6 258.0 110 3.08 3.215 19.44 1 0 3 1
Valiant 18.1 6 225.0 105 2.76 3.460 20.22 1 0 3 1
Merc 280 19.2 6 167.6 123 3.92 3.440 18.30 1 0 4 4
Merc 280C 17.8 6 167.6 123 3.92 3.440 18.90 1 0 4 4
Ferrari Dino 19.7 6 145.0 175 3.62 2.770 15.50 0 1 5 6
``` ::: ::: ### Multiple conditions ::: {.cell execution_count=15} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.query("cyl == 6 & hp > 105") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=15} ```{=html}
mpg cyl disp hp drat wt qsec vs am gear carb
Mazda RX4 21.0 6 160.0 110 3.90 2.620 16.46 0 1 4 4
Mazda RX4 Wag 21.0 6 160.0 110 3.90 2.875 17.02 0 1 4 4
Hornet 4 Drive 21.4 6 258.0 110 3.08 3.215 19.44 1 0 3 1
Merc 280 19.2 6 167.6 123 3.92 3.440 18.30 1 0 4 4
Merc 280C 17.8 6 167.6 123 3.92 3.440 18.90 1 0 4 4
Ferrari Dino 19.7 6 145.0 175 3.62 2.770 15.50 0 1 5 6
``` ::: ::: ## Sorting ### Ascending ::: {.cell execution_count=16} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.mpg.sort_values().head(10) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=16} ``` Lincoln Continental 10.4 Cadillac Fleetwood 10.4 Camaro Z28 13.3 Duster 360 14.3 Chrysler Imperial 14.7 Maserati Bora 15.0 Merc 450SLC 15.2 AMC Javelin 15.2 Dodge Challenger 15.5 Ford Pantera L 15.8 Name: mpg, dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: ### Descending There is no 'descending' per se, just set `ascending` to False. ::: {.cell execution_count=17} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.mpg.sort_values(ascending = False).head(10) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=17} ``` Toyota Corolla 33.9 Fiat 128 32.4 Lotus Europa 30.4 Honda Civic 30.4 Fiat X1-9 27.3 Porsche 914-2 26.0 Merc 240D 24.4 Datsun 710 22.8 Merc 230 22.8 Toyota Corona 21.5 Name: mpg, dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: ## Applying functions ### Map a function with no arguments to a single column ::: {.cell execution_count=18} ``` {.python .cell-code} # some function to apply def increment(x): return x+1 # could also be done as a lambda expression df["ApplyResult"] = df.mpg.map(increment) df[["mpg", "ApplyResult"]].head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=18} ```{=html}
mpg ApplyResult
Mazda RX4 21.0 22.0
Mazda RX4 Wag 21.0 22.0
Datsun 710 22.8 23.8
Hornet 4 Drive 21.4 22.4
Hornet Sportabout 18.7 19.7
``` ::: ::: ### Apply a function with arguments using kwargs ::: {.cell execution_count=19} ``` {.python .cell-code} # some function yadda def incrementBy(x, by): return x + by # could also be done as a lambda expression df["ApplyResult"] = df.mpg.apply(incrementBy, by = 5) df[["mpg", "ApplyResult"]].head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=19} ```{=html}
mpg ApplyResult
Mazda RX4 21.0 26.0
Mazda RX4 Wag 21.0 26.0
Datsun 710 22.8 27.8
Hornet 4 Drive 21.4 26.4
Hornet Sportabout 18.7 23.7
``` ::: ::: ## Missing values Expanding on an example from [here](https://datatofish.com/check-nan-pandas-dataframe/). Pandas uses `np.nan` instead of `NA`. ::: {.cell execution_count=20} ``` {.python .cell-code} df2 = pd.DataFrame({ "x": [1,2,3,4,5,np.nan,7,8,np.nan,10,11,12,np.nan], "y": [1,np.nan,3,4,5,6,np.nan,8,9,10,11,12,13] }) df2 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=20} ```{=html}
x y
0 1.0 1.0
1 2.0 NaN
2 3.0 3.0
3 4.0 4.0
4 5.0 5.0
5 NaN 6.0
6 7.0 NaN
7 8.0 8.0
8 NaN 9.0
9 10.0 10.0
10 11.0 11.0
11 12.0 12.0
12 NaN 13.0
``` ::: ::: ### Missing in the whole df ::: {.cell execution_count=21} ``` {.python .cell-code} # no NA the whole thing df2.isnull() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=21} ```{=html}
x y
0 False False
1 False True
2 False False
3 False False
4 False False
5 True False
6 False True
7 False False
8 True False
9 False False
10 False False
11 False False
12 True False
``` ::: ::: ### Missing in a single column ::: {.cell execution_count=22} ``` {.python .cell-code} # just the x column df2.x.isnull() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=22} ``` 0 False 1 False 2 False 3 False 4 False 5 True 6 False 7 False 8 True 9 False 10 False 11 False 12 True Name: x, dtype: bool ``` ::: ::: ### Replace NAs in a column ::: {.cell execution_count=23} ``` {.python .cell-code} # use the fillna function df2.x = df2.x.fillna("MISSING") df2 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=23} ```{=html}
x y
0 1.0 1.0
1 2.0 NaN
2 3.0 3.0
3 4.0 4.0
4 5.0 5.0
5 MISSING 6.0
6 7.0 NaN
7 8.0 8.0
8 MISSING 9.0
9 10.0 10.0
10 11.0 11.0
11 12.0 12.0
12 MISSING 13.0
``` ::: ::: ### Replace the NAs in the full dataset ::: {.cell execution_count=24} ``` {.python .cell-code} # files the other even though I didn't specify a column df2.fillna("MISSING!!!") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=24} ```{=html}
x y
0 1.0 1.0
1 2.0 MISSING!!!
2 3.0 3.0
3 4.0 4.0
4 5.0 5.0
5 MISSING 6.0
6 7.0 MISSING!!!
7 8.0 8.0
8 MISSING 9.0
9 10.0 10.0
10 11.0 11.0
11 12.0 12.0
12 MISSING 13.0
``` ::: ::: ### Drop NAs The [official docs](https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/reference/api/pandas.DataFrame.dropna.html) are great on this. ::: {.cell execution_count=25} ``` {.python .cell-code} # create another sample df df3 = pd.DataFrame({ "x": [1,np.nan,3,4,5,np.nan,np.nan,8,np.nan,10,11,12,np.nan], "y": [1,np.nan,3,4,5,6,np.nan,8,9,10,11,12,np.nan], "z": [1,2,np.nan,4,5,6,np.nan,8,9,10,11,12,np.nan] }) df3 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=25} ```{=html}
x y z
0 1.0 1.0 1.0
1 NaN NaN 2.0
2 3.0 3.0 NaN
3 4.0 4.0 4.0
4 5.0 5.0 5.0
5 NaN 6.0 6.0
6 NaN NaN NaN
7 8.0 8.0 8.0
8 NaN 9.0 9.0
9 10.0 10.0 10.0
10 11.0 11.0 11.0
11 12.0 12.0 12.0
12 NaN NaN NaN
``` ::: ::: #### Drop all across the df ::: {.cell execution_count=26} ``` {.python .cell-code} # no NAs period df3.dropna() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=26} ```{=html}
x y z
0 1.0 1.0 1.0
3 4.0 4.0 4.0
4 5.0 5.0 5.0
7 8.0 8.0 8.0
9 10.0 10.0 10.0
10 11.0 11.0 11.0
11 12.0 12.0 12.0
``` ::: ::: #### Drop if they're all na in that row ::: {.cell execution_count=27} ``` {.python .cell-code} # drop if the whole row is NA df3.dropna(how = "all") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=27} ```{=html}
x y z
0 1.0 1.0 1.0
1 NaN NaN 2.0
2 3.0 3.0 NaN
3 4.0 4.0 4.0
4 5.0 5.0 5.0
5 NaN 6.0 6.0
7 8.0 8.0 8.0
8 NaN 9.0 9.0
9 10.0 10.0 10.0
10 11.0 11.0 11.0
11 12.0 12.0 12.0
``` ::: ::: #### Drop all in certain columns This is so clutch! Much simpler than filtering across in R (though there might be a cleaner way for that) ::: {.cell execution_count=28} ``` {.python .cell-code} df3.dropna(subset = ["x", "y"]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=28} ```{=html}
x y z
0 1.0 1.0 1.0
2 3.0 3.0 NaN
3 4.0 4.0 4.0
4 5.0 5.0 5.0
7 8.0 8.0 8.0
9 10.0 10.0 10.0
10 11.0 11.0 11.0
11 12.0 12.0 12.0
``` ::: ::: ## Group & Summarize ### Group by a factor level ::: {.cell execution_count=29} ``` {.python .cell-code} df[["mpg", "disp", "cyl"]].groupby(by = "cyl") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=29} ``` ``` ::: ::: ### Groupby factor level and get the mean ::: {.cell execution_count=30} ``` {.python .cell-code} df[["mpg", "disp", "cyl"]].groupby(by = "cyl").mean() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=30} ```{=html}
mpg disp
cyl
4 26.663636 105.136364
6 19.742857 183.314286
8 15.100000 353.100000
``` ::: ::: ## Melting a DataFrame ::: {.cell execution_count=31} ``` {.python .cell-code} # use the melt function specifying ids and value vars df_long = pd.melt(df, id_vars = "cyl", value_vars = ["mpg", "wt"]) df_long ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=31} ```{=html}
cyl variable value
0 6 mpg 21.000
1 6 mpg 21.000
2 4 mpg 22.800
3 6 mpg 21.400
4 8 mpg 18.700
... ... ... ...
59 4 wt 1.513
60 8 wt 3.170
61 6 wt 2.770
62 8 wt 3.570
63 4 wt 2.780

64 rows Ã— 3 columns

``` ::: ::: ## Misc ### Counts of values (like `table` in R) ::: {.cell execution_count=32} ``` {.python .cell-code} # shows how many there are of each factor df.cyl.value_counts() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=32} ``` 8 14 4 11 6 7 Name: cyl, dtype: int64 ``` ::: ::: ### Formatting long chains ::: {.cell execution_count=33} ``` {.python .cell-code} # a little ugly but it works df[["mpg", "disp", "cyl"]].\ query("cyl > 4").\ groupby(by = "cyl").\ mean() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=33} ```{=html}
mpg disp
cyl
6 19.742857 183.314286
8 15.100000 353.100000
``` ::: ::: ### Iterating over a df For mutating the dataframe apply/map is recommended, but I'm showing how to do this for completeness. ::: {.cell execution_count=34} ``` {.python .cell-code} for i, j in df.iterrows(): print(df["mpg"][i]) # j would give you all the columns with just that row ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 21.0 21.0 22.8 21.4 18.7 18.1 14.3 24.4 22.8 19.2 17.8 16.4 17.3 15.2 10.4 10.4 14.7 32.4 30.4 33.9 21.5 15.5 15.2 13.3 19.2 27.3 26.0 30.4 15.8 19.7 15.0 21.4 ``` ::: ::: https://www.statsmodels.org/stable/examples/notebooks/generated/glm.html https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/linear-regression-in-python-using-statsmodels/ https://datagy.io/pandas-iterate-over-rows/ https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/getting_started/comparison/comparison_with_r.html
